rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1: â
'''Necrophilia''' is a [[paraphilia]] characterized by a sexual attraction to [[corpse]]s. This has been a charactistic of several [[serial killer]]s, notably [[Ed Gein]], though it is very rare even in that context. There have been numerous cases of necrophiles working in the [[funeral]] business, as it provides them with easy access to corpses.
+
'''Necrophilia''' is a [[paraphilia]] characterized by a sexual attraction to nonresponsive persons, including the [[coma]]tose and [[corpse]]s. Necrophilia is a primary movitve behind the use of incapacitating chemicals (such as [[GHB]]) to commit date [[rape]].
â
In [[California]], there were laws against mutilating a corpse or digging it out of a grave, but not against having sex with it. However, this changed on [[September 10]], [[2004]], when [[Governor of California|Governor]] [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] signed a bill making necrophilic acts a felony punishable by up to eight years in prison. [http://www.sfexaminer.com/article/index.cfm/i/042204n_charges][http://www.reuters.com/newsArticle.jhtml?type=domesticNews&storyID=6208717]
+
Falsely, necrophilia is sometimes restricted to "sexual attraction to corpses". This variety of necrophilia is a notable [[subset]] of the paraphilia, but not all-encompassing.
â
In [[Colorado]] it might be covered by the [[misdemeanor]] "treats the body or remains of any person in a way that would outrage normal family sensibilities" (Colorado Statutes/Title 18 Criminal Code/Article 13 Miscellaneous Offenses/18-13-101. Abuse Of A Corpse).
+
Necrophilia has also been a motive for some [[serial killers]], including [[Ed Gein]] and [[Jeffrey Dahmer]], who ate his victims after killing them. Several other [[murder]]ers have described drawing sexual excitement from killing, as well, such as [[Karla Faye Tucker]], who claimed to have an [[orgasm]] with each swing of the [[axe]] she used to kill [[Jerry Lynn Dean]].
â
Similarly in [[Alabama]], where it was considered that sexual acts with a body may constitute "abuse of a corpse", but not rape. [http://www.ca11.uscourts.gov/opinions/ops/19966752.OP.pdf]
+
In come cases, necrophiliacs work in the [[funeral]] business, presumably for the facile access to [[human]] corpses.
â
In the [[United Kingdom]], [[sexual penetration]] of a corpse was banned with the new [[Sexual Offences Act 2003]], which makes it punishable by up to two years in prison.
+
== Legal status ==
  +
As psychological abnormalities, necrophiliac attractions and fantasies are not specifically illegal, and "necro porn" does not have the same status as [[child pornography]] (almost invariantly illegal and outrage-provoking). It would not be possible, in most cases anyway, to infer, with legal proof, nonresponsivity from a pornographic image. [[BDSM]] or [[sexual role-playing | role-playing]] practices that simulate nonresponsivity one the part of one person are completely legal.
  +   +
However, having sex with a dead person is outlawed in most localities (and socially accepted almost nowhere.) Drugging a living person into a nonresponsive state for sexual purposes is usually classified as [[rape]] and punished severely. If the person dies as a result of the drug, the party responsible can also be tried for murder.
  +   +
The [[United Kingdom]] outlawed [[sexual penetration]] of a corpse in the [[Sexual Offenses Act 2003]], making the act punishable by up to two years in prison. Many [[United States | U.S.]] states prohibit such acts, though often under vague terms outlawing "abuse of a corpse".
  +   +
Until [[2004]], [[California]] had laws against mutilation of corpses and [[grave robbery]], but none specifically against sex with corpses. On [[September 10]], [[2004]], [[Governor of California | Governor]] [[Arnold Schwarenegger]] signed a bill making such acts a felony, with maximum sentence of eight years in [[prison]]. [http://www.reuters.com/newsArticle.jhtml?type=domesticNews&storyID=6208717]
  +   +
== Consensuality issue ==
  +   +
Necrophilia against an unknown corpse is generally considered socially unacceptable; since the person would not have consented to the act while alive, it amounts to the [[rape]] of a dead body, and virtually all human [[society | societies]] condemn abuse of the dead. However, in rare cases, necrophiliac acts can be consensual: for example, in the [[Armin Meiwes]] case, the victim gave his consent to the mutilation and death inflicted upon him.
